body:
One option would be use the LiveRender class to redraw the table each time. But frankly I think this is a rather niche requirement and I suspect there are better ways of presenting your information.

I don't see the worth in documenting something which I doubt would be expected of a terminal rendering of a table.

Closing this as wontfix. But if you have a concrete proposal of how a progressive table would work / look like I'll listen.

I would love to see this feature too. I have a stream of data that is being received which I want to format as a table. Since I have many rows, I would like to have the ability to print new rows as data is being received without the need to re-render the entire table. As it was said above, we will need to set column widths before printing. 
A code example might look like:
```python
from rich.console import Console
from rich.table import ProgressiveTable

console = Console()
table = ProgressiveTable()

table.add_column('test column', width=12)

table.add_row('first row')
console.print(table)

table.add_row('second row')
console.print(table)

table.finish_border()
console.print(table)
```

Whose output should be 
```
┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃ test column  ┃
┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩
│ first row    │
│ second row   │
└──────────────┘
```

Such a table would probably work by buffering the newly added rows before printing (only) them.

@giladreti Rich current main goal is to provide the building blocks for creating TUI applications. As my primary use case was for making console application output easier to read, I created a small extension called [enrich](https://github.com/pycontribs/enrich/) which focuses on progressive and fluid output (soft wrapping, for both console and logging).

Even so this will may not work for tables because they can work only with a fixed layout and rich needs to decide how much space to give to each column and do the wrapping. I think you could emulate it by styling the table to render as a single row and printing each row as an entire table.

To be honest the rendering of UI elements is a very complex issue for which browsers spent decades improving and I doubt @willmcgugan has the superpowers to address it.

For the moment I avoid printing stuff as tables if progressive display is needed or if the total amount of printed rows is likely to be bigger than 1-2 screens.
